Space & Astronomy.name: Asteroid Rendezvous
Space & Astronomy.description: Test your knowledge of NASA's missions and celestial bodies! This quiz focuses on specific events and objects in our solar system, from asteroid orbits to stellar names.

questions.text: On Valentine's Day 2000, NASA's NEAR spacecraft began a yearlong orbit of what asteroid?
questions.hint: The asteroid’s name is fitting for a Valentine’s Day mission, tied to love.

questions.text: On Valentine's Day 2000, NASA's NEAR spacecraft began a yearlong orbit of what asteroid?
questions.hint: The asteroid’s name is fitting for a Valentine’s Day mission, tied to love.

questions.text: What is the meaning of 'Betelgeuse', the name of the brightest star in the constellation Orion?
questions.hint: The name reflects a part of the giant’s body in Arabic astronomy.

Space & Astronomy.name: Saturn's Secrets
Space & Astronomy.description: Delve into the mysteries of Saturn and its moons! This quiz explores the forces at play in our solar system and the fascinating details of the ringed planet's satellites.

questions.text: What force causes an ice cream cone to fly off of a spinning merry-go-round?
questions.hint: This force is related to the outward pull felt on spinning objects.

questions.text: Phoebe, Dione and Helene are moons of what planet?
questions.hint: This planet is famous for its extensive ring system.

questions.text: Phoebe, Dione and Helene are moons of what planet?
questions.hint: This planet is famous for its extensive ring system.

Space & Astronomy.name: Cosmic Rhythms
Space & Astronomy.description: From the speed of light to the birthplace of a jazz legend, this quiz blends astronomy with unexpected trivia. Prepare for a whirlwind tour of the universe and beyond!

questions.text: Where did jazz great Sun Ra claim he was born?
questions.hint: His claimed birthplace is a planet, reflecting his cosmic musical persona.

questions.text: What is the approximate speed of light?
questions.hint: This speed is incredibly fast, measured in miles per second, not hour.
